Bolivia: Meet the Candidates 2025
=================================

![](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/RB-Headshot-e1704321264443.jpg)

By [Rich Brown](https://americasquarterly.org/aq-author/rich-brown/) |   
July 24, 2025

Amid the collapse of the MAS as a dominant political force, the opposition is making polling gains ahead of the August 17 presidential election.

![From left: Samuel Doria Medina; Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga; Andrónico Rodríguez](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/CandidatesArtBolivia_070825-scaled.jpg)

From left: Samuel Doria Medina; Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga; Andrónico Rodríguez 

Reading Time:   < 1 minute

In the August 17 general elections, Bolivians will vote for president, vice president, and all seats in both houses of the legislature. In the race for president, if no candidate secures more than 50% of the vote or a 10-percentage-point advantage over the rest of the field, the two leading contenders will head to a runoff scheduled for October 19. The presidential and legislative winners will all take office on November 8.

The country’s deep [economic crisis](https://americasquarterly.org/article/escape-economic-crisis-bolivia/) is top-of-mind for voters as inflation, fuel shortages, and a lack of formal employment opportunities continue to weigh on the public. President Luis Arce has [opted](https://apnews.com/article/bolivia-elections-morales-arce-race-campaign-polls-leftwing-9296923408ddcfa429aff4cf9e3e7626) not to run for reelection, and a Constitutional Court ruling in May [barred](https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/bolivia-top-court-upholds-ruling-blocking-morales-election-eligibility-2025-05-14/) former President Evo Morales from participating.

The candidates polling over 10% in a July [Ipsos Ciesmori](https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2025/07/14/mas-incertidumbre-electoral-en-bolivia-por-nueva-encuesta-en-la-que-sube-el-voto-blanco-nulo-e-indeciso/) survey are included below in alphabetical order by last name. *AQ* asked a dozen nonpartisan experts on Bolivia to help us identify where each candidate stands on two spectrums: left versus right on economic matters, and personalistic versus institutionalist on leadership style. We’ve published the averages of their responses, with a caveat: Platforms evolve, and so do candidates. We will occasionally update this page to reflect developments in the campaigns.

![](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/Cand_Bolivia_Medina.jpg)

Samuel Doria Medina
-------------------

### 66, business magnate and former minister of planning

#### Alianza Unidad

##### “We have the best team and a serious plan to stabilize the economy in 100 days.”

#### **HOW HE GOT HERE**

Doria is one of the country’s wealthiest businessmen and is running for president for the fourth time. He led Soboce, the country’s biggest cement manufacturer, from 1987 until he [sold](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2014/12/16/691838/34261/en/Samuel-Doria-Medina-Sells-Soboce-to-Completely-Devote-Himself-to-the-Bolivian-People.html) his controlling stake for around [$300 million](https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2025/06/29/samuel-doria-medina-candidato-a-presidente-de-bolivia-en-los-ultimos-20-anos-el-gobierno-ha-cohabitado-con-el-narcotrafico/) in 2014 to mount a presidential bid. He has led other large [companies](https://www.noticiasfides.com/nacional/politica/doria-medina-a-garcia-linera-no-conozco-a-gustavo-vedia-y-no-soy-dueno-de-subway--365669-365580) and built Bolivia’s [tallest skyscraper](https://greentower.com.bo/la-paz). A longtime centrist and social democrat, he was minister of planning (1991-93) in the administration of President Jaime Paz Zamora. In the 2020 election, he was incumbent President Jeanine Áñez’s [running mate](https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2020/02/02/jeanine-anez-eligio-a-samuel-doria-medina-como-companero-de-formula-para-las-elecciones-en-bolivia/) before they [dropped out](https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-54200128) of the race amid poor polling. He is now at the head of the largest opposition [coalition](https://es-us.noticias.yahoo.com/samuel-doria-medina-inscribe-alianza-234750859.html), Unidad, which includes prominent groups like Creemos, backed by Luis Fernando Camacho, and Comunidad Ciudadana, led by former President Carlos Mesa.

#### **WHY HE MIGHT WIN**

Given President Arce’s [lack of popular support](https://x.com/cidgallup/status/1889078200346583506/photo/1), the [rifts within the ruling MAS party](https://americasquarterly.org/article/bolivia-enters-contentious-new-political-landscape/), and the country’s [economic straits](https://americasquarterly.org/article/escape-economic-crisis-bolivia/), many voters appear ready to support a moderate opposition candidate. As a centrist, Doria Medina may attract former MAS supporters who are looking for an alternative outside of the conservative right. His [background in business](https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2025/06/29/samuel-doria-medina-candidato-a-presidente-de-bolivia-en-los-ultimos-20-anos-el-gobierno-ha-cohabitado-con-el-narcotrafico/) allows him to maintain that he is a political outsider, and his track record of entrepreneurial success lends credibility to his claims that he can fix the economy. He has shown with Unidad that he can lead a coalition, and recently won the backing of [Marcelo Claure](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-07-18/bolivia-s-richest-man-backs-a-millionaire-candidate-in-bid-to-oust-the-left?sref=5LmjrEiv), Bolivia’s richest man.

#### **WHY HE MIGHT LOSE**

Some voters might prefer other moderate candidates with more government experience. Doria Medina’s reputation as a perennial presidential candidate may be detrimental to his outsider image. He could also be overtaken by candidates further to the right, who have adopted a less conciliatory and more aggressive stance toward the MAS and the status quo.

#### **WHO SUPPORTS HIM**

He has broad name recognition and appears to be drawing support from both longtime moderate MAS opponents and voters who have more recently soured on the ruling party. His supporters tend to believe that he is the opposition candidate most likely to unite enough of the country behind him to win. Doria Medina’s strongest support comes from the middle classes, with the poorest individuals tending to lean toward leftist candidates and the richest tending to lean further to the right. As the candidate of the broadest opposition coalition, he has won endorsements from [public intellectuals](https://eldeber.com.bo/pais/vicente-cuellar-renuncia-su-candidatura-y-mantiene-su-apoyo-samuel_514268/) and business leaders alike.

#### **WHAT HE WOULD DO**

Like all leading candidates, he plans to [reduce](https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2025/06/29/samuel-doria-medina-candidato-a-presidente-de-bolivia-en-los-ultimos-20-anos-el-gobierno-ha-cohabitado-con-el-narcotrafico/) fuel and other subsidies to cut government spending. Doria Medina emphasizes [transparency](https://www.noticiasfides.com/nacional/politica/doria-medina-ve-prioritario-que-el-gobierno-trabaje-en-recuperar-la-credibilidad-del-censo-418614), incentives for small businesses, and reductions in taxes and red tape for the private sector. He favors [shutting down](https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2025/06/29/samuel-doria-medina-candidato-a-presidente-de-bolivia-en-los-ultimos-20-anos-el-gobierno-ha-cohabitado-con-el-narcotrafico/) certain state-owned businesses and [deals](https://www.oep.org.bo/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/PROGRAMA-DE-GOBIERNO-ALIANZA-UNIDAD.pdf) with the IMF and other multilateral organizations to liberalize the economy more broadly, while also supporting certain poverty-reduction spending. His party [platform](https://www.oep.org.bo/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/PROGRAMA-DE-GOBIERNO-ALIANZA-UNIDAD.pdf) vows not to cut cash transfer programs.

#### IDEOLOGY

![](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/IdeologyBOLIVIA_0709252-scaled.jpg)

![](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/Cand_Bolivia_Rodiriguez.jpg)

Andrónico Rodríguez
-------------------

### 36, Senate president

#### Alianza Popular

##### “I want to promote a new way of doing politics in which dialogue, compromise and social peace come first.”

#### **HOW HE GOT HERE**

Andrónico, as he is popularly known, has been a [longtime MAS member](https://www.bbc.com/mundo/articles/cy8d709nejno) and president of the Senate since 2020, when he first won public office. He hails from Cochabamba, the cocalero organizing stronghold where his father was a Quechua campesino leader and his mother worked for a union. After studying political science, Rodríguez [worked his way](https://www.latercera.com/mundo/noticia/andy-joven-protegido-evo-morales-aspira-convertirse-sucesor/867443/) up the ranks of Bolivia’s biggest coca growers’ association, eventually replacing Evo Morales as its president in 2019. In this organization, he was Morales’s protégé and close confidant, remaining as the federation’s leader during his presidency (2006-19). He [agreed](https://www.diario-red.com/articulo/america-latina/alianza-popular-bolivia-confirma-andronico-rodriguez-como-candidato-presidencial/20250519120000047676.html) to run for president with the leftist Alianza Popular coalition in May.

#### **WHY HE MIGHT WIN**

Grassroots movements that support the MAS could largely back Rodríguez. Other MAS-affiliated candidates are [polling](https://elpais.bo/nacional/20250601_samuel-y-tuto-lideran-la-primera-encuesta-nacional-de-candidatos-inscritos-a-las-elecciones-2025.html?__cf_chl_tk=P4RQpjj6ZfCEY0m5pGWh56NaqEfQDK3T07yVZFR1WQU-1752007354-1.0.1.1-qbLlGO8xZIjGLR0iSGJazOCf85LEntT1lo4m0Vfs9Gg#google_vignette) in the single digits, and Rodríguez may be able to attract MAS supporters while also appealing to other voters as a fresh face less associated with the establishment. Rodríguez’s closer alignment with the Morales wing of the MAS over Arce’s also distances him somewhat from the unpopular incumbent. For now, Morales continues to [criticize](https://www.reduno.com.bo/noticias/evo-arremete-contra-andronico-y-lo-acusa-de-representar-intereses-de-la-derecha-2025713125143) Rodríguez and withhold his support, as Rodríguez insists that he should be allowed to run for president.

#### **WHY HE MIGHT LOSE**

Due to his association with the MAS, Rodríguez may fall victim to the general anti-incumbent mood amid the country’s economic decline under Arce’s government. Some Morales supporters may refuse to vote for him, and other MAS voters may align with other candidates. Recent [protests](https://apnews.com/article/bolivia-evo-morales-protestas-elecciones-candidatura-inhabilitacion-a1e0e3fa8eaeac5c303e6e950d3ef5ea) in support of Morales’ attempt to run for president have in some cases turned violent. Rodríguez lacks executive experience in government and has thus far appeared only [sparingly](https://www.vision360.bo/noticias/2025/07/15/28445-andronico-elude-nuevamente-un-foro-electoral-con-el-mismo-argumento-razones-de-agenda) in the media and candidate [forums](https://www.vision360.bo/noticias/2025/07/15/28445-andronico-elude-nuevamente-un-foro-electoral-con-el-mismo-argumento-razones-de-agenda).

#### **WHO SUPPORTS HIM**

Rodríguez has support from the major campesino organizing fronts he has interacted with throughout his career. He is likely to draw votes from rural Bolivians who are often undercounted in the polls. As the youngest candidate, he may also appeal to voters who seek an alternative to established political figures.

#### **WHAT HE WOULD DO**

Rodríguez has said he would gradually [reduce](https://www.opinion.com.bo/articulo/pais/andronico-habla-responde-evo-combustibles-plan-gobierno-entrevista/20250707005356975909.html) fuel and other subsidies, in line with his Alianza Popular party’s “[intelligent austerity](https://www.oep.org.bo/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/PROGRAMA-DE-GOBIERNO-ALIANZA-POPULAR.pdf)” proposals, and try to reduce government spending by prioritizing the most disadvantaged sectors while cutting down on bureaucracy, redundancy, and waste. To inject dollars into the economy, he [has said](https://www.reduno.com.bo/noticias/como-traera-andronico-rodriguez-dolares-para-bolivia-conoce-su-propuesta-economica-20257219945) he favors seeking loans from groups like BRICS over traditional lenders like the IMF. He also aims to boost exports by offering incentives to the private sector, but would also maintain strong government involvement in key areas like mining and tourism, as well as [push](https://www.oep.org.bo/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/PROGRAMA-DE-GOBIERNO-ALIANZA-POPULAR.pdf) import substitution through tariffs on certain sectors.

#### IDEOLOGY

![](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/IdeologyBOLIVIA_070925-scaled.jpg)

![](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/Cand_Bolivia_Quiroga.jpg)

Jorge “Tuto” Quiroga
--------------------

### 65, former president

#### Alianza Libre

##### “The first thing I will do when I get to the Palace of Government is return stability to the country.”

#### **HOW HE GOT HERE**

[“Tuto” Quiroga](https://clubmadrid.org/who/members/quiroga-jorge-fernando/) served as president from 2001-2, and has run for president three times before, most recently in 2020, [dropping out](https://www.lostiempos.com/actualidad/pais/20201011/semana-elecciones-tuto-quiroga-declina-su-candidatura-presidencia) before the election amid poor polling. He was finance minister under Zamora for eight months in 1992, and five years later, he became the country’s youngest-ever vice president in the administration of President [Hugo Bánzer](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Hugo-Banzer-Suarez). Bánzer was a controversial figure who had been a [right-wing military dictator](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Hugo-Banzer-Suarez) from 1971, when he led a coup d’état, until he was deposed in 1978. In 2001, Bánzer resigned due to ill health, and Quiroga completed Bánzer’s term but opted not to run for reelection. He has worked for major Bolivian mining and banking firms as well as the IMF and the World Bank. He is running with the Libre coalition after [leaving](https://eldeber.com.bo/pais/tras-ruptura-del-bloque-de-unidad-tuto-afirma-que-esta-condenado-entenderse-con-samuel_510027/) a broader opposition group that largely opted to support Doria Medina.

#### **WHY HE MIGHT WIN**

Quiroga is the main standard-bearer for Bolivia’s right wing in this election, and he has long warned that the MAS’ economic populism would lead to the kind of fiscal and economic crunch that has come to pass. He may be able to capitalize on widespread discontent with how Arce and the MAS have handled the economy by offering the sharpest contrast to the ruling party among all leading candidates.

#### **WHY HE MIGHT LOSE**

Quiroga didn’t gain traction when he ran for president in 2020 and may struggle to attract moderates, limiting his appeal beyond his conservative base. His close association with Bánzer and the unpopular record of Bánzer’s presidency could alienate some voters.

#### **WHO SUPPORTS HIM**

As a long-standing and vocal critic of the MAS, Quiroga is popular among the country’s most conservative voters and many of those disillusioned by the Arce government. He appeals to voters who roundly reject the MAS and its economic project, and who seek a return to pre-2005 Bolivia. Quiroga has strong support among the upper classes, especially in La Paz, and major players in the private sector.

#### **WHAT HE WOULD DO**

Quiroga would aim to dramatically shrink the government’s role in the economy and its spending. He [advocates](https://www.oep.org.bo/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/PROGRAMA-DE-GOBIERNO-ALIANZA-LIBERTAD-Y-DEMOCRACIA.pdf) an IMF rescue package and favors stricter austerity measures than other candidates. Quiroga has also spoken of digitalizing government to make it more efficient and transparent, and said he would give every adult in the country a [“popular property title”](https://elperiodico.com.bo/tuto-quiroga-intensifica-campana-con-su-oferta-de-titulo-de-propiedad-popular-por-us-1-500/) worth $1,500, as a symbolic share of the country’s natural resources that can be used to access loans.

#### IDEOLOGY

![](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/IdeologyBOLIVIA_0709253-scaled.jpg)

To Escape Economic Crisis, Bolivia Has a Painful Road Ahead: Whoever wins this year’s election, the next president will face the daunting task of implementing bitter reforms.](https://americasquarterly.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/BOLsupermarket.jpg)

Customers outside a subsidized grocery store in La Paz in Sept. 2024. Manuel Seoane/Bloomberg via Getty Images 

Reading Time:   4 minutes

LA PAZ—Bolivia is heading into uncharted territory as the August 17 elections near. For the first time in two decades, former President Evo Morales, the leader of the [once-dominant](https://americasquarterly.org/article/bolivia-enters-contentious-new-political-landscape/) Movimiento al Socialismo (MAS) will not appear anywhere on the ballot. Meanwhile, the public is preparing to vote with [inflation](https://tradingeconomics.com/bolivia/inflation-cpi) at 24%, its highest level in over three decades, making the presidential race an unpredictable test for the political system and its institutions.

For Bolivians, it is a wholly new experience to see [polls indicating](https://brujuladigital.net/politica/2025/06/18/samuel-lidera-encuesta-de-el-deber-con-24-de-intencion-de-voto-jorge-tuto-quiroga-le-sigue-con-22-47660) that two right-wing opposition leaders, most likely Samuel Doria Medina and Jorge Quiroga, could advance to a runoff on October 19. The reason, polling suggests, is that economic concerns now [outweigh](https://www.reduno.com.bo/noticias/encuesta-nacional-que-dicen-los-bolivianos-sobre-la-economia-del-pais-y-de-sus-familias--2025327202231) political ones for most Bolivians amid a [crisis](https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/bolivias-economy-on-the-brink/) marked by a shortage of U.S. dollars, scarce fuel, and rising inflation. In the country’s highly polarized environment, [protests](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-07-02/bolivia-inflation-soars-to-34-year-high-ahead-of-august-election) occur almost daily, and highway blockades in the countryside are exacerbating the shortages.

No matter who wins, the next president will have to implement painful reforms. These include reducing a fiscal deficit that has hovered around 10% for years, possibly tripling domestic fuel prices, and negotiating with international lenders, such as the International Monetary Fund, to secure the dollars needed to stabilize the economy and the nation’s foreign trade.

In a report on May 30, the IMF [recommended](https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2025/05/30/pr-25168-bolivia-imf-concludes-2025-art-iv-consult) that Bolivia adopt “a credible and sustained fiscal consolidation” to rationalize the nation’s wages, phase out fuel subsidies, enhance public investment and spending efficiency, and boost tax revenue. “Eliminating monetary financing of fiscal deficits is also important,” the multilateral lender stated, noting that the country’s central bank has financed the deficit despite tight external conditions and the fact that public debt has increased to 95% of GDP.

President Luis Arce, who has opted not to seek reelection due to his low approval ratings, continues to defend his administration. Earlier this week, he [blamed](https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2025/07/22/luis-arce-justifica-la-crisis-economica-de-bolivia-los-culpables-estan-sentados-en-la-asamblea) national lawmakers for failing to pass key bills that would authorize external funding. “When there are economic problems, they point to the government as if we were the culprits,” Arce said Arce said at a public event in La Paz. “The culprits are sitting in the Legislative Assembly, because they don’t approve loans, because they want to make us look bad in front of the people by saying we don’t know how to do anything.” According to Arce’s Planning Ministry, the legislative branch has 17 bills under review that are expected to trigger $1.7 billion in investments.

**A cascading dollar crisis**

At the turn of the century and during its first decade, high commodity prices lifted many economies in Latin America, and Bolivia became the [second-largest beneficiary](https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/bolivias-economy-on-the-brink) of the boom, behind only Venezuela. By 2014, Bolivia had accumulated nearly [$14 billion](https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/bolivias-economy-on-the-brink/) in foreign reserves, largely thanks to gas exports. However, the country failed to encourage enough exploration, and government gas revenue plummeted from $5.5 billion a decade ago to under $1.6 billion last year.

The government, nevertheless, has maintained expensive subsidies and propped up a [fixed exchange rate](https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/bolivias-economy-on-the-brink/), and the country now likely has well under $2 billion in reserves. Most of that is gold, and the central bank may hold less than [$50 million](https://www.fitchratings.com/research/sovereigns/fitch-downgrades-bolivia-to-ccc-24-01-2025) in hard foreign currency reserves, Fitch Ratings said when it downgraded the nation’s credit rating to CCC- in January.

Fuel subsidies have been a major source of spending, amounting to [nearly $3 billion](https://www.infobae.com/america/america-latina/2024/11/25/presupuesto-de-bolivia-en-2025-preve-continuar-con-la-subvencion-de-combustibles-se-destinaran-56-millones-de-dolares-a-la-semana/) annually. Now, due to the fiscal crunch, the government imports less, resulting in common shortages. Long lines have formed at gas stations across the country, where truck and car drivers sometimes wait days to fill their tanks.

All major presidential hopefuls, even the leading MAS-aligned candidate, Andrónico Rodríguez, agree that fuel subsidies will need to be cut—the only questions are how much, how fast, and how intensely the public will protest. Fuel prices could triple without subsidies. When the agribusiness group [Anapo](https://www.linkedin.com/company/anapobolivia) announced a month ago that it had begun [importing fuel](https://brujuladigital.net/economia/2025/06/11/anapo-importa-su-propio-diesel-a-bs-135-el-litro-47359) from Brazil, it said it was paying more than three times the domestic selling price.

Meanwhile, the process of attracting new investment in the gas sector could take years. It would likely require broad political consensus on the need for significant reform to cut taxes on the gas industry and otherwise incentivize private sector participation. Even then, the government would also need to work to convince investors that Bolivia is overall a credible investment destination.

**Addressing the shortage**

The shortage of U.S. dollars has hit imports across the board, worsening inflation for basic goods, including medicines. The fixed exchange rate maintained by the Arce administration has become untenable. For the first time in 40 years, a black-market dollar rate has emerged. For now, the dollar gets around [14 bolivianos](https://www.reduno.com.bo/noticias/a-cuanto-se-cotiza-el-dolar-paralelo-en-bolivia-este-domingo-20-de-julio-vuelve-a-bajar-202572073947) on the black market compared to just 6.96 bolivianos through official channels.

Dollar shortages have become so severe that a banking “*corralito*” has taken hold: Depositors are unable to withdraw dollars from their accounts and are instead given bolivianos at the official rate. Devaluation is already a reality on the street, and a painful official devaluation seems all but inevitable.

Arce has been unable to attract dollars to right the ship. His efforts to approve lithium contracts that promise [$1.4 billion](https://www.voanews.com/a/chinese-russian-firms-to-build-lithium-plants-in-bolivia/7160921.html) in investment from a Chinese and a Russian company, for example, have stalled in the Legislative Assembly, due largely to the ruling party’s internal divisions. The situation is no better in the broader mining sector; gold exports generate minimal revenue for the state, and the [Mutún iron plant](https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bolivia-set-start-up-china-funded-steel-plant-2025-02-13/) has only just begun operations.

The major candidates all agree that to bolster the supply of dollars the country will need to secure major loans. Opposition candidates are focused on the IMF and similar multilateral lenders, while Andrónico Rodríguez, the leading MAS-affiliated leftist candidate, [leans instead](https://www.reduno.com.bo/noticias/como-traera-andronico-rodriguez-dolares-para-bolivia-conoce-su-propuesta-economica-20257219945) toward options like BRICS.

Any deal will require tradeoffs. Traditional multilateral loans will demand significant spending cuts as well as measures to improve transparency in public finances*.* It may also be necessary to shut down loss-making state-owned enterprises and lay off a number of public employees, for example.

These challenges await whoever becomes the next president. If an opposition candidate wins and the right returns to power after two decades in the wilderness, painful rationalization measures will threaten the administration’s stability. If the leftist Rodríguez prevails, he may well also face a hostile majority in the new legislature. The road out of Bolivia’s economic crisis will be a hard one for whatever government takes shape.
